Thanks for your response. I will close the issue now.
Have you tried running the script because it works.
@jdhines exactly , it's used to modify extension.

@bravesnail Ah, ok. I do see that now. I guess I was confused by the comments saying it would rename a batch of files, but didn't mention that it's purpose was just to rename extensions. My recent use cases for batch rename are renaming a bunch of images with generic names (like img001.jpg) to something else (like my_neat_event_20151231_1.jpg), so that was my frame of reference.
I think I went a little crazy on that... sorry if that is too much.

No worries, thanks for making the improvements

Cheers
Craig

On 18 Feb 2016, at 20:39, Doug Mahugh notifications@github.com wrote:

> FYI, you can use enumerate() to simplify osinfo.py. Instead of this:
> 
> i=1
> for item in profile:
> print( '#',i,' ',item)
> i=i+1;
> 
> ... do this ...
> 
> for i, item in enumerate(profile, 1):
> print( '#',i,' ',item)
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

add get_youtube_view.py details

Especially if you're on Unix/Linux. I'm pretty sure you could use the following code to tell what operating system you're on and adjust accordingly:

```
from sys import platform as _platform
if _platform == "linux" or _platform == "linux2":        #Linux
    # Trash will be in ~/.local/share/Trash
elif _platform == "darwin":        #OS X
    # Trash will be in ~/.Trash
elif _platform == "win32":        #Windows
    # I *think* the recycle bin is in C:\$Recycle.bin
```
